title: How to Winterize Your RV Without Costly Mistakes: Step-by-Step Visual Guide (2025)
excerpt: Avoid burst pipes, dead batteries, and mold. Expert step-by-step guide + real 2025 product picks to winterize your RV like a pro‚Äîsafely and affordably.

content.text: Two winters ago, my friend Mark stored his camper without properly draining the water lines. Result? $2,300 in repairs, mold in the cabinets, and a ruined spring trip.
Don't let that happen to you.

Winterizing your RV isn't just about "putting it away." It's about protecting your investment, your comfort, and your next adventure. And yes‚Äîyou can do it right without being a mechanic or spending a fortune.
In this guide, we'll walk you through exactly how to winterize your RV like a pro, using real 2025 products, field-tested tips, and mistakes you must avoid at all costs.
‚ùÑÔ∏è Why Proper RV Winterizing Matters More Than You Think
Winter is your RV's silent enemy. Extreme cold can:

items: Burst pipes from freezing (even if they're "mostly empty"!)
Destroy your water pump due to trapped ice
Completely drain your battery in weeks
Create hidden mold from trapped interior moisture

content.text: The good news? With under 45 minutes and less than $150, you can prevent 95% of these issues.
üõ†Ô∏è Step-by-Step: How to Winterize Your RV (Visual Guide)
‚úÖ Step 1: Clean and Dry the Entire Interior
Empty the fridge, scrub the bathroom, remove damp towels. Moisture is mold's best friend.
üí° Pro Tip: Leave an open box of baking soda or a portable desiccant to absorb moisture throughout winter.
‚úÖ Step 2: Drain and Blow Out the Water System

items: Open all faucets (hot and cold)
Open low-point drain valves on tanks
Use an RV-specific air compressor (60‚Äì80 PSI) to blow residual water from lines

content.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Common mistake: Using an unregulated air compressor. You can crack fittings or seals!
‚úÖ Step 3: Add Non-Toxic RV Antifreeze
Never use automotive antifreeze‚Äîit's toxic. Use pink, non-toxic RV antifreeze.
Pour it directly into drain traps, toilets, and shower lines‚Äîor into the fresh water tank if you're using the pump method.
‚úÖ Step 4: Protect the Battery

items: Disconnect it completely
Store it in a cool, dry place (not your freezing garage!)
Use a solar battery maintainer if you'll leave it connected

content.text: ‚úÖ Step 5: Cover and Ventilate
Use a breathable RV cover‚Äînever plastic sheeting. And leave a window slightly cracked or install passive solar vents for airflow.

Not all gear is created equal. These are the ones we use, test, and trust:

Purpose: Protect pipes without toxicity | Pros: NSF-certified, easy pour spout | Cons: Takes up storage space
Purpose: Keep battery topped off all winter | Pros: Works on cloudy days, plug-and-play | Cons: Not for large battery banks

üíö Expert Tip: "I never put antifreeze in the fresh water tank unless I'm 100% sure I'll flush it thoroughly in spring. I prefer blowing out lines with air and only using antifreeze in P-traps and shower drains." ‚Äî Carlos, RV Technician since 2012
‚ùå 3 Winterizing Mistakes That Destroy RVs (And How to Avoid Them)

items: "It's dry‚Äîno antifreeze needed." ‚Üí Residual vapor freezes. Always protect drain traps.
Leaving the battery connected "just in case." ‚Üí It'll drain dead in 3 weeks. Disconnect it.
Using a plastic tarp as a cover. ‚Üí Traps condensation. Only use breathable RV covers.

Proper winterizing isn't an expense‚Äîit's peace of mind. Imagine this:
